title: How many times will the Federal Open Market Committee raise the federal funds rate between 7 March and 30 September 2018?
preds:
There were 3 rate rises in the time period 07-03 to 30-09. Mar 21, 2018 — 1.50–1.75
Jun 13, 2018 — 1.75–2.00
Sep 26, 2018 — 2.00–2.25
https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Federal_funds_rate That means the first two buckets are eliminated. The FOMC also projects one more hike before the end of the year and three in 2019.
https://www.cnbc.com/2018/09/26/fed-hikes-rates-by-a-quarter-point.html The next meeting when a rate rise could occur is after September 30, eliminating the last bucket. So only 3 rate rises are possible in the time period of this question, but 4 for the whole year.
there is near certainty of a rate rise today, which would put it at 3x.
Updating forecast.  The FOMC made their third rate rise during their September meeting.  No further rate rises are expected during the contest period.
Updating to 95% as markets already have priced in a rise. Thanks, @cdob63.

http://www.profitf.com/calendars/fomc-meeting-schedule/
Day after tomorrow is their last chance before this deadline.   Almost sure a hike will happen then, but if it doesn't happen by Wednesday it won't happen this month.

https://www.nytimes.com/2018/09/23/business/us-tariffs-on-chinese-goods-to-take-effect-and-the-fed-will-meet.html?emc=edit_mbae_20180923&nl=morning-briefing-asia&nlid=7782502520180923&te=1 "Markets have already priced in a quarter-point increase on Wednesday, and investors see the odds of another quarter-point increase in December as better than 90 percent.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-fomc/feds-powell-between-a-rock-and-hard-place-ignore-the-yield-curve-or-tight-job-market-idUSKCN1M10D5 "WASHINGTON (Reuters) - Unemployment near a 20-year low screams at the U.S. Federal Reserve to raise interest rates or risk a too-hot economy. The bond market, not far from a state that typically precedes a recession, says not so fast. The decision of which to heed looms large when the Fed’s interest-rate setters meet next week. Which path they follow will begin to define whether Chairman Jerome Powell engineers a sustained, recession-free era of full employment, or spoils the party with interest rate increases that prove too much for the economy to swallow. New Fed staff research and Powell’s own remarks seem to put more weight on the risks of super-tight labor markets, which could mean a shift up in the Fed’s rate outlook and a tougher tone in its rhetoric. Goldman Sachs economists, for instance, contend the Fed’s “optimal” rate path is “well above market pricing under a broad range of assumptions.” They see four increases likely next year, while investors expect only one or two, a significant gap. Fed officials have telegraphed a likely quarter-point rate increase when they meet on Tuesday and Wednesday next week, and investors expect that, plus another in December.
~~~~~~~
COMMENT:  I think 97% for 3 raises is correct for this CY, but I'm not that confident there will be 3 by 10/1.

The economy may be going well, but the debt is still paid for with this interest and there's a lot of it.  Also, reducing the rate too much could have a significant negative effect on the world economy. They probably need to tighten a little, but not too much... and given the recent number of strikes for higher pay, inflation will start to become a concern.

The number of Hawks on the FOMC far outnumbers the number of Doves.
With unemployment at 20 year lows, wages steadily increasing and strong growth figures, it's almost inconceivable that the FED wouldn't take this opportunity to raise rates again. The base rate is probably the most important weapon in their arsenal for combating recessions, it would be foolish not to reload, so to speak. 5% is included for the distinct possibility that they are indeed foolish.
Its possible that the rate will be continue to be increased not just because the US economy appears to be healthy, but to give some room for rate drops if the trade war leads to a crash.
They're gearing up for the next big plooper.
If Florence hits the east coast as hard as even Hugo did - they'll pause the hikes.

As per Christopher's reasoning, since they have already made 2 rate rises in this time period and have claimed four for 2018, there is time for just 1 more in the time period. https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/770426

The Economist asks, "How many times ﻿﻿﻿﻿will the Federal Open Market Committee raise the federal funds rate between 7 March and 30 September 2018?" My forecast: Less than 2: 0%    |   2 times: 0%  | 3 times: 100% | 4 or more: 0% I contend that the Federal Open Market Committee will raise the federal funds rate between the dates aforementioned three times for several reasons. First, the Federal Open Market Committee has already raised the federal ﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿﻿funds rate two times between the specified dates, thus the answer cannot be less than 2. (https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/openmarket.htm) Second, FOMC made these rate hikes every three months in 2018, on March 22 and June 14, thus it is expected that they will raise the rates in September. (https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/openmarket.htm) Third, FOMC is meeting again before the specified end date for this forecast, as the Committee is convening on September 25-26, meaning that the number of hikes cannot exceed 3. (https://www.federalreserve.gov/monetarypolicy/fomccalendars.htm). Lastly, FOMC has signaled that it intends to hike rates two more times this year, and will do so at its September meeting. (https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/13/us/politics/federal-reserve-raises-interest-rates.html)

Already raised twice, on 21 March and 13 June. One more announcement is to be made, on 26 September, before this question's deadline, and the market assigns a 98.4% probability that the rate will be raised.
https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html

1137 373 .85 .15 was 1085 355 86 14 on Sept01. 
Was 97-3 now 100 on 3.
Edit: Sept 27th 1257 from 392 0.94 on 3 and 6% on 2 raises (the inactives). Did 17 bets (too many) there was 16 bets in past day.  
Was a fun q. Go Powell! Wish I went more aggressive in July with theory of overheating caution.

1137 373 .85 .15 was 1085 355 86 14 on Sept01. 
Was 97-3 now 100 on 3.  Edit: oops didn't change numbers.

They have raised it twice as of 9/8/18. There is another meeting of the Committee on 9/25. The members have stated they expect to raise the rates three times in 2018, and the 9/25 meeting will present a good chance to see how third quarter has been going and allow them to adjust if they see fit. The other meetings are 11/7 and 12/18, which fall outside the scope of this question. If the Committee intends to raise the rates as they have insinuated, the 9/25 meeting will be the likely time to do so.

Updating from 0/8/92/0. Market consensus is now at 99% chance of another raise on 26 September [1]. Average over past week is over 98%. Being a little conservative and risk-averse. [1] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/
Updating my forecast to account for some of the political pressure coming from the White House.

https://www.cnbc.com/2018/07/27/el-erian-skeptical-fed-will-hike-in-september-despite-92percent-probability.html "Economist Mohamed El-Erian told CNBC on Friday the probability of a September rate hike by the Federal Reserve is well below what traders believe." "Fed officials including Chairman Jerome Powell have raised interest rates twice this year and have indicated two more are coming before the end of 2018. The CME FedWatch tool, which is based on Fed fund futures trading, put the chances of a September rate increase at 91.4 percent on Friday." "I think that's way too high," the chief economic advisor at Allianz said on "Squawk Box." "If I looked only at the U.S., I would buy the 92 percent. But I think there are other things happening in the world." "El-Erian's probability of a rate hike was above 50 percent because of "headwinds from the rest of the world."" Worth considering his opinion, however everything else I've read makes a Sept. rate hike sound like a done deal.
Actual inflation is ~ 10% per year because Ronald Reagan removed housing costs from the CPI in 1983.
Based on economic conditions, inflation rate, global factors and FED traditions to show independence from administration.

Two increases so far. Before the deadline, there is only one more FOMC meeting (on 25th & 26th September) and press conference. The markets seem to expect them to increase the federal funds rate at that meeting.
The Fed has signaled a likelihood of 4 rate hikes this year with the 3rd in September and the 4th in December.

Politically un-feasible to raise it again before the election - if the market took an adjustment afterwords they'd get the blame - plus inflation ins finally starting to tick in the preferred direction - up, though largely due to energy prices.

1085 from 355 86-14 
Does Powell obey Trumpy? We don't really know yet. 
Was 95-5 now 97-3.
Mortgages are languishing despite low rates. Construction is already off and winter is coming. I think they pause on the hikes.

Updating from 0/10/90/0 due to continued indications from the Fed that hikes will keep happening, and market consensus that odds are around 95% [1]. [1] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/

The Fed made it pretty clear they are going to raise rates at their September meeting. https://www.washingtonpost.com/business/fed-minutes-suggest-further-rate-hikes-coming-soon/2018/08/22/c525a310-a635-11e8-ad6f-080770dcddc2_story.html?noredirect=on&utm_term=.0d84a587504e

1017 from 340 bettors now 83-17 was 940 from 332 @0.78 on August 2nd. 
was 92-8 now 95-5.
The Fed will fulfill its recommendation of 2 raises in that time period.
Updating my forecast.  The 31 July - 1 August meeting resulted in rates being held at current level.  I still believe that September will be the third rate hike for contest period.

Traders expect the Fed to raise borrowing costs twice more this year. They see a 92% probability that it will raise the fed funds rate to a range of 2% to 2.25% in September, according to Bloomberg.
https://www.businessinsider.com/federal-reserve-fomc-statement-interest-rates-august-1-2018-8

New home construction and Mortgage applications have taken a drop. Rates are up. The fed strengthened its outlook on the economy but the construction trades which are an employment driver would suffer under a new rate hike too soon so I think the Fed sits pat till after the election when weather usually slows down construction anyway...

already raised 2x and with last deceision in september, they have raised every other and unless there is a big setback economically i would put the odds hight they will raise. Fed said expect two rate rises by end of year, with futures market prices 91% rise in September and 70% rise in December.

Updating from 0/18/82/0 in view of language from today's Fed meeting [1], confirmed by market movement [2]. [1] https://www.cnbc.com/2018/08/01/fomc-august-rate-decision.html
[2] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/

The Federal Open Market Committee votes unanimously to keep the target range for its benchmark rate at 1.75 percent to 2 percent.
The committee says "economic activity has been rising at a strong rate," a more bullish view than the June characterization of "solid" growth.
The statement also notes that household spending has "grown strongly."
Following @CubsWin on the basis of his brilliant performance in the Chief Financial Officers challenge.
I would think today's GDP numbers makes three nearly a done deal and brings a fourth into play.

2 raises as of 27/7 and 2 more opportunities before 30/9
inflation is at 2.9 in June (2.8 in May), so a further raise is likely.
However GDP growth is slower and unemployment rate is climbing up again, so that could make the FOMC pause
https://tradingeconomics.com/united-states/indicators

As they have already raised rates twice we are close to three. If the economy continues to strengthen I suspect we see another rate increase. However, trump's trade war may cause an economic slowdown as prices increase and companies lose out in export markets due to retaliatory tariffs. If we start to see negative economic indicators I don't think the fed raises again.

Updating from 0/25/75/0 as the market has been over 85% for the past week at least [1], which seems like enough time for it to process Trump's tweets about the interest rate. [1] https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/
0-10-89-1, well definitely no chance of '4 or more' now. Moving 1% to the twice box 0-11-89-0 Will it backfire on Trumpy again? Maybe Powell will cower or prove independence.

Trump says he does not like rate increases. That is going to make it harder for the Fed to back off a Fall interest rate increase.  Plus the economy is strengthening as businesses rush ahead of tariff increases.

Two rate increases have already happened and it highly unlikely they will raise rates without a press conference; there is no press conference scheduled for the meeting on July 31-Aug 1.  Ergo, there will be only one more rate increase from now.  High Q2 GDP numbers and higher inflation rates will likely cause a rate increase in September.
Less than 3 shakes confidence, more than 3 and international markets feel it.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed/fed-emphasizes-solid-u-s-economic-growth-repeats-gradual-approach-idUSKBN1K325Z
I expect to be sorry for moving up on this one.

The trade wars will slow economic activity whilst the economy adjusts to the new global trade dynamics and the FOMC will hold off on the Aug/Sep rate increase to assist with these adjustments that businesses will be making.
Hourly rate went up higher than the crowd thought.   Switch from 53-47-0 to 10-89-1.  Some market commentators are saying 2 more rises this year (September and December).  WoC 63 & 37 799 from 313
Updating on latest economic data and new market expectations: https://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/
Economy is going well and wage inflation is likely to occur soon.
I think we about to have an energy boom and inflation will require more hikes.

Trump's tax cuts have had no net effect on economic growth for the average American, as inflation increases as reported by hte CPI of 2.8% year over year have effectively offset increase in take-home income, therefore economic growth per capita hasn't increased, but corporate earning continue to grow .  Additionally, the spread between 2 and 10 year treasury bonds are as close as they were in 2007 and 2002, precipitating a recession in both instances.  Finally, the ECB and Chinese regulator authorities have chosen not to follow the Fed's most recent decision to raise rates, increasing the spread between US T-Bonds and others, sending investors and capital flocking back to US bond markets, which triggered massive price decreases in Italian and Argentinian government bonds.  Should prevailing forces in the White House continue this path of "US First, World Second," it's likely that we'll see further rate increases to better position the US bonds in capital markets compared to the Rest of the World.
If the economy grinds to a halt and the Fed lowers the rate, does it resolve as 1? Or is it still 2 raises with one drop?
Two hikes delivered and Fed's still on track for a hike in every quarter as inflation crawls higher and activity remains strong. Market's pricing an 80% probability that they would hike on Sep 26.

This is just a guess, but it seems to me US trade tensions with China and many others will make it harder for the Fed to raise rates in September. It seems there is a good chance the impact on the economy will be a natural slowing in investment (due to uncertainty) and consumptions (due to inflation), thus doing the job of higher interest rates without the Fed having to raise them.  CME has the odds at near 70% (link below). I am still above 50%, but reduced from my pervious 75%. http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html
It's gonna be a wild year...
CME market has the probability at 84% for a Sep increase.  http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html

"The Federal Reserve raised interest rates on Wednesday and signaled that two additional increases were on the way this year, as officials expressed confidence that the United States economy was strong enough for borrowing costs to rise without choking off economic growth." https://www.nytimes.com/2018/06/13/us/politics/federal-reserve-raises-interest-rates.html

4 meetings left and 2 anticipated rate hikes. Assuming that one rate hike will occur during the July/September meeting and the other during the November/December time frame.
https://www.marketwatch.com/story/fomc-lifts-fed-funds-rate-to-175-2-signals-4-hikes-in-2018-2018-06-13
https://www.nafcu.org/newsroom/fomc-sets-tentative-2018-meeting-schedule
Updating my forecast after today's rate rise from the FOMC -- which gives us two.  I still believe we'll see the third after the September meeting, giving a total of three for the contest period.
Now thinking whether the hike today has an affect and doesn't require another one until December.  Depends how the trade wars and prices go.

The FOMC is divided: eight members believe 4 hikes are needed, seven - three hikes. But even the three-hike group would probably vote for a hike in September, followed by a pause in December - the other way around doesn't make much sense. Unless trade wars slow the US economy already by September - but this seems a low-probability event (too soon).

The Fed indicated more hawkish approach at its meeting this week. [1] Market expectations have responded [2] [1] https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-13/fed-raises-rates-officials-boost-outlook-to-four-hikes-in-2018
[2] http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/

"4 or more" -4
"2" +3
"3" +1  
Revised from previous a few minutes ago recognizing that the vote is at 8-7 for 4 total hikes, so 7 are still thinking there will be three.  Highly unlikely both will be in the next couple meetings, as close to 40% are predicting a hike in December, and no one appears to be predicting 5 rate hikes, so that leaves us with a very low chance for 4 or more.

"2" -12
"3" +10
"4" + 2 Just raised again for a second time.  Historically over the past year+ have raised every other meeting.  Fed is predicting 4 total raises for this year.  With 2 meetings left in the time period, there is a good chance there will be at least one more raise.
"Federal Reserve officials raised interest rates for the second time this year and upgraded their forecast to four total increases in 2018, as unemployment falls and inflation overshoots their target faster than previously projected." https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-06-13/fed-raises-rates-officials-boost-outlook-to-four-hikes-in-2018
Fed comments make 3 look more likely.

They've just hiked the rates for the second time in the timeframe, making "less than 2" definitely impossible. The 15 economists also shifted from a 3-vs-4-hikes-this-year score of 8-vs-7 to 7-vs-8. Since 4 hikes this year almost surely implies another hike on 26 Sep, and 3 hikes this year still probably implies a hike on 26 Sep (at the very least to leave themselves the option of a 4th hike in Dec, instead of being stuck at 3 for 2018), I want to say only 10% chance question resolves as "2", and 90% as "3". But I don't really know that much about interest rates so I'll de-extremize to 25/75. [1] https://www.marketwatch.com/story/fed-hikes-interest-rates-now-sees-4-moves-this-year-2018-06-13

Interest rates will remain stable to counter an unstable president.  The feds will be wary of Trump's trade war effects on the economy and keep interests low in hope to offset as much as possible the effects of Trump's stupidity.

I am updating my previous forecasts due to new information on employment and wages, current and projected inflation, and the Fed's balance sheet. I still believe that there will be three rate rises before this contest ends, but I believe that the chances of four are nil.  I also believe that there is a slightly stronger chance for just two rate rises.

Most articles point to several more increases, and traders are betting on June and September hikes, putting a likelihood of 3 in the time period of the question.   +18 for "3"
-20 for "2"
-1 for "Less than 2"
+3 for "4 or more" "After the expected June increase the Fed’s target interest rate will be set at a range of between 1.75 percent and 2 percent, matching the Fed’s inflation target and roughly in-line with the latest inflation data. That translates to a real rate of roughly zero and is already at neutral, according to some policymakers who feel the Fed should stop hiking now." https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-rates-analysis/fed-clambers-back-to-positive-real-rates-now-debate-is-when-to-stop-idUSKCN1J30DE "The U.S. Federal Reserve is increasingly likely to raise rates a fourth time this year after a government report showed employers added more jobs than expected in May, bets by traders in short-term interest-rate futures showed. Traders remain quite confident of rate increases in June and September, prices of the futures show, and see about a 36 percent chance of a rate hike in December, up from about 32 percent before the report. The Fed has raised rates once this year so far, in March. Traders also increased bets on further rate increases in 2019." https://money.usnews.com/investing/news/articles/2018-06-01/traders-boost-bets-on-fed-interest-rate-rises https://www.gjopen.com/comments/comments/742323
Shifting a little lower given the most recent fed forecast.

The jobs data is looking very good and so are company earnings in practically all sectors. These 2 factors will put upward pressure on wages which will lead to upwards pressure on inflation which will lead to upward pressure on rates - July & September increases of 25 basis points each. The dynamics of the economy will then settle for the remainder of the year whilst the 3 rate increases for the year are digested and accommodated.
Raising probability of 3 on latest jobs report: https://www.cnbc.com/2018/06/04/us-treasurys-lower-as-market-takes-a-breather-after-jobs-report.html

"Of the 15 Fed board members, six anticipate the Fed will hike four times this year and one believes five hikes will be necessary. It's not quite enough to tip the official forecast to four rate increases, but it's getting close." https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/wonk/wp/2018/03/21/federal-reserve-hikes-u-s-interest-rate-to-highest-level-in-a-decade-amid-stronger-economy/?noredirect=on&utm_term=.339f478ef8b8 "The May employment report was seen as strong across the board and certainly prompts the Federal Reserve to raise interest rates in 12 days, but it doesn’t settle the larger debate over whether there will be three or four total moves this year." https://www.thebalance.com/fomc-meetings-schedule-and-statement-summaries-3305975 5 total meetings remaining in the year, 3 within the timeframe of this question.
https://www.thebalance.com/fomc-meetings-schedule-and-statement-summaries-3305975 Facts and assumptions:
1. From the articles I have read, there is a strong case for 3 or 4 total rate hikes this year.
2. There has already been 1 this year (March)
3. There are 5 remaining meetings this year, 3 within the timeframe of this question.
4. Historically over the past year, the rate seems to have a pattern of raising every other meeting. Given the debate, I start off with looking at the full year, and just decided to give a 50/50 split to whether it will be 3 or 4 for the year.  So the realistic question becomes, "will there be 1, 2, or 3 more raises before September 30th?   If there are 2 more rate hikes this year (for a total of 3), then the likelihood, just based on the remaining 5 meetings, is about 30% that both will happen prior to the end of the year, and a 60% likelihood that there will only be 1 more.  The remaining 10% is for 0 more raises.   If there are 3 more rate hikes this year (for a total of 4), then the likelihood, is about  20% for 1 more, 70% for 2 more, and 10% for 3 more.   So given that we don't know if there will be 3 this year or 4, I will weigh both evenly.  
0 raises: 5%
1 raise: 40%
2 raises: 50%
3 raises: 5% Now, given the current news, and a likely raise on June 12th, I am deducting 4 points from "Less than 2", and giving 2 points to "2", 1 point to "3", and 1 point to "4 or more". This brings me to my forecast above.  This will update on the week of the 12th, after the next meeting.   Given the nature that the group typically raises every other meeting, and it is highly unlikely to see increases 3 meetings in a row, I am reducing "4 or more" by 5 points, and giving them all to "3".

I am updating my previous forecast.  I believe that there will be a second rate hike this month (June) based on recently released employment figures and other macroeconomic variables. I'm still predicting three rate hikes for the period, at the end of each quarterly meeting -- March (already occurred), June, and September.
The job numbers, even if revised down later, were strong enough for the futures to react  - http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/
Updating on latest market consensus as per: http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/
Updating from 0/34/61/5 due to no change in May meeting. Also, today some opening shots of a trade war were fired.

1) Start with market implied probabilities via the CME here: http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html 3.9% -less than 2
41.2% - 2
53.8% - 3
1.1% - 4 2) Trump is allowing more visas!
http://thehill.com/latino/389437-homeland-security-announces-additional-h-2b-visas-for-companies-at-risk-of-failure I have a hard time coming up with more bullish wage increase indicators. I bump up 3 more, decrease 2, set less than 2 to zero.
I ultimately think there will be 4 hikes in the year, but because the question cuts at Sept 30 I give zero for 4 as well.

WoC at 61 and 3 raises @38%.  Only chance of a 3 raise is the Trumpy chaos and thought bubble policy method stops which is Buckley's chance. And inflation magically stops. With oil up, wages up, full employment and tariff mess that's making a 2 case stronger.

May Fed meetings revealed that consumer spending grew less than the Fed expected. On top of this, the Fed hinted at a willingness to let inflation waver symmetrically around 2%, suggesting they may be ok if inflation tops 2% temporarily. Both of these suggest a looser monetary policy, i.e. fewer rate hikes. Still though, the overarching message from the minutes is that the Fed worries about overheating and expects to raise rates 2 more times this year, maybe 4. [1] The CME forecast for a September hike went down a few percentage points [2] to 68%. I am similarly adjusting down. [1] https://www.nytimes.com/2018/05/23/business/fed-minutes-may-meeting.html
[2] http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/

Adjusting probability of 3 raises slightly based on May meeting minutes. On one hand FED seems positive about economic growth and markets are pricing probability of Jun and Sep raises pretty high. On the other hand FED appears to be willing to have inflation exceed 2% and might hold off raising too fast. Net result of my adjustment is slight increase of 3 raise probability at the expense of 1 and 2 raises scenarios.
1 hike already in March, expectations for 2 further by end of Sept

Attempt at modeling different paths of raise/no raise over the remaining 3 meetings with conditional probabilities of each decision. Parameters of the estimate are largely made up giving lower probability to 2 consecutive rate increases given that inflation as seen by FOMC is close to their target and recent NFP numbers were below estimate.
market participants will push fed to go slow in increases even though new head is committed to slow rise
one more scheduled and then another on oil inflation

Consumer Price Index for All Urban Consumers 0,2 (it may be changes in transportation services, airline fares and new vehicles - according to higher prices for oil and metalls) and  Nonalcoholic beverages.
Unemployment rate in april 3.9 (reduced from 4.1)
https://www.bls.gov/cpi/tables/supplemental-files/home.htm
https://data.bls.gov/timeseries/LNS14000000
Most likely raise rate in June again due to the economic growth conditions, but too strong $ is not good for the US economic growth, so the raising pace should not be too fast.
To stay on track for 3 or 4 interest rate hikes in the year, this should be the expected amount given when meetings are scheduled.

Fed already has 1 rate hike on March 21, after March 7 date. So, how many rate hike between now and Sept 30?
Argument for only 1 more:
- Inflation is close to 2%, but Fed would allow inflation to overshoot a bit to compensate for long period of no inflation;
- The cloud of trade war is looming over the horizon, as long as it is menacing, a too quickly rate hike would tank the economy. 
Argument for 2 more rate hikes:
- The effect of the tax cut just started to be felt, and the economy may be heating up quickly, making the Fed to act quicker
- Trade war was just talk to talk. Depending on what Mnuchin and the chief negotiator (Ben Ross?) bring back from China, we may have to revise the odds. If China conceeds, then more rate hikes. If not, less.

https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-fed-rates/fed-likely-to-keep-rates-steady-investors-bet-on-june-hike-idUSKBN1I22TC
apparently nothing this meeting, but probably next time
The Fed meeting this week is unlikely to announce additional interest rates. However, we should expect an announcement of an increase at its next meeting in June.
T bond yields down slightly but more importantly core inflation up at 1,9% which is close to 2,0% target. More rate increases on the way.

Updating from 0/30/67/3 as the market seems to be coming down on the 3 bucket [1] --- currently at 66.7%, down from as high as 75%. [1] http://www.cmegroup.com/trading/interest-rates/countdown-to-fomc.html/

Data from 1990 shows the following counts of rate changes per calendar year (and %): <2, 14, 50%
2, 0, 0%
3, 7, 25%
>=4, 7, 25% The average number per annum is 2.9. There are two outliers; 1991 (10 change), 2001 (11 changes). Interestingly, no years have had just two changes. I'm not sure if this is just random variation or if there is something that the FOMC doesn't like about just two changes.  There has also been an unusually quiet period from Dec '08 to Jan '16. March, November and December seem to have the highest number of changes. Adjusting from 0/45/55/0 due to evolution of market sentiment as gleaned from [1]. There is currently near-certainty (95+%) of at least one more hike by June, which is why I keep lowest bucket at 0%. The market also says the breakdown for Sep is 1.5/31.7/61.3/5.4. In the past I'd have gone with this exact forecast, but since joining PredictIt I have gained a new appreciation for the effects of illiquidity. Namely, even if I believed the 1.5% on the lowest bucket is right or too low, the expected gains from arbitraging this opportunity are very low, and take too long to realize, so I leave it alone. Same for the 5.4% at the other extreme. (I'm not super confident in this reasoning.) In general, I feel like the effect of costly arbitrage is for the extremes to not reach their "true" extreme prices, so I take the market prediction and smoosh it towards the middle: 0/38/60/2. Revised to take into account Minneapolis Fed's comment about labor market, about some thought on recent tax cut, on Fed's balance sheet, on deficit spending bill this week, on threat of trade war. 1. Labor Market
   - Fed has dual mandate: target inflation to 2% and full employment
   - The official unemployment is about 4% (which is normally considered full employment), but because of the prolong recession, labor participation is still low and there is more room for it to run up. This also account for the absent of wage increase pressure.
   Rising rate cool down economy, slow down rate of job creation, so this is an argument against more frequent rate hike. 2. Recent Tax Law
  - Prior to 2017, US Corporations parked income earned overseas to avoid paying repatriation tax;
  - They invest mostly on short term bonds, and that may include US treasury bonds;
  - They issue bonds in the US to raise money to pay dividends, buy back stocks.
  - In 2018, US companies doesn't have much incentive to park money overseas and will use the money to buy back their bonds.
   - Stop buying and start selling short term bonds -> bond price lower, yield higher on short term;
   - Stop selling and buy back corporate bonds -> bond price higher, yield lower on medium and long term;
   These have effect of flattening the yield curve, spooked the market in February. While the net effect on cost of capital isn't clear, it seems this would increase the cost of economic activity over all, since economic activities are more affected by medium to long term bonds yield. (Thinking of 30 year mortgage interest, 10 year bond for expansion). Since hiking rate is just a tool to increase cost of capital, if yield already increase, there would be less need for increasing lending rate. 3. Fed Balance Sheet
 - During Quantitative Easing (QE), Fed print money to buy bonds, forcing bond price up, yield down and increase money in circulation.
 - Now Fed is letting short-term bond mature, in effect flatten the yield curve by not buying new short-term bonds to replace what expired. This also decrease money in circulation.
 There is talk that Fed may have to do an inverse-QE: sell long term bonds to buy some short term bonds, renormalize the yield curve. This would somewhat cool down the economy for reasons explained in (2) above. 4. Trade War
  - Everybody agrees that a full fledge trade war with China would plunge the world back into recession, eliminates the chance of rate increase for the rest of the year;
  - But trade war comes in many shapes and forms. There is the real one, and there is the fake one. So far, Trump has not announced the extensive ones yet. Chinese respond seems to be restrained. The most significant answer from China was not slapping back tariff on steel and recycled aluminum or pork, or wine, but the threat of not buying as much treasury. 
 - There is also talk that Trump recent move was to coral China into cooperation about North Korea.    Not buying treasury means price lower, yield higher, raising the cost of capital. 5. Deficit Spending
 - The US continue on its trajectory of increasing deficit, meaning it will have to issue more treasury bonds, decrease bond price and increase cost of borrowing. I believe there will be one more rate increase between now and September 30. The three rate hikes people talked about is during 2018, not until Sep 30. There could still be chance to have 2 more until Sept 30, and none in December. We will have to watch carefully the bond market, next week inflation readings and whatever happens from the White House.
Revise the odds after today's decision and speech.

The FOMC kept its median view of 3 hikes in 2018. Assuming that this is their baseline, it implies that they will skip a hike in one of the live meetings (June, Sep, Dec). Which one? June is the least likely candidate, as the current momentum should be sustained in the short run (barring shocks, of course, but here we are talking about the baseline). September: no if the economy is doing as the Fed expects (well) in Q2-Q3. So under the Fed's current baseline, the answer to this question will likely be 3 hikes (March, June, September). Now, what can go wrong with the economy between now and September? First, policy shocks - a trade war with China certainly qualifies. This will likely start playing out already in Q2. Second, a sharp move up in market (Treasury bonds) interest rates - spooked by the large fiscal deficit (projected at over $800 billion in the fiscal year ending at Sep 30, 2018), and perhaps a drop in foreign demand for Treasuries. This I see more likely for Q3-Q4, if it comes at all. Third, the expected short-term tailwind from fiscal policy (tax cuts + expenditure hikes) may be weaker than expected (labor shortages may play a role). This will only be known by September, if not later, given data lags.  Overall, I'd say a June hike is a high-probability even (say, 95%), preventable only by a large-scale trade war with China (and others - the EU?) unfolding already in Q2. For September, I am leaning 70-30 in favor of a hike. This yields the forecast above. To be reassessed after (1) we see what, if any, trade sanctions are imposed on China and the Chinese reaction, and (2) economic growth in Q1 (together with wages/employment dynamics in March/April).

In contrast to others, I believe there is fundamentals will show little reason to raise rates in March. 
The Fed have two new tools (GDP Nowcasts) that show declining rates of growths.   (3.5% in December, 2.83% in March).   I believe that having increased rates in December, and seeing growth lower sharply, there is no chance they will raise in March. More tellingly, the Fed lowered its target for full employment from 4.8% to 4.6%.   
The Fed has dual goals:  lowering inflation and ensuring full employment.   Lowering the  target of full employment is a tell for two factors. First.  In the discussion of employment, the Fed noted that worker participation in the usual prime employment ages is down more than 2.5%.    They correctly noted that there is more than adequate slack in employment to absorb future employment gains, even considering retirement data.  Second.  Dropping the full employment rate to 4.6% is a tacit admission that the number they had previously considered full employment (somehow) is not actually as useful a barometer of employment as previously.   The historical norm has been reached, suggesting that there should be significant wage pressure - and yet there is not.   The Fed essentially punted on an explanation - merely guessing that structural changes have changed where the full employment number is.  Either way, lowering the full employment number combined with the mandate for full employment, suggests that the fed will continue to have tolerance for easy money policy. Additionally, inflation.  Much of the fed discussion focused around how inflation is currently under their target rate of 2.0 percent.   Core inflation is 1.7%    There are no inflationary pressures to argue for higher interest  rates.   Plus the Fed is hypersensitive to the worries of deflation that occured in the last recession. As I write this, oil markets have just dropped from their peak of $70 to $62.   Energy costs are the primary component of core inflation; inflationary pressures will lower over the next month.  Our economies are rather like drowning swimmers.  In the early 70's unbridled by crippling debt 'normal' interests rates were 7%.  However, after each subsequent recession the new maximum has declined 6%.. 5%.. 4%.. and so it must, as western nations are drowning in  huge amounts of debt, that were interest rates to rise they could not pay.    Yield curves have already flattened.  The point:  The Fed's expectation over interest rate rises is predicated by its past experiences.   In earlier times, the fed might make 8 or 10 interest rate changes.  And so based on bygone experience the fed publishes that they expect 4 interest rate changes this year.   But current circumstance do not afford that robustness.  The Fed will want to raise interest rates - because it has only very few tools at its disposal. It has the ability to raise interest rates - and lower interest rates.  It knows that with interest rates sitting at 1.25-1.5% that it has very little wiggle room during the next recession.  And so it would like to raise those rates, certainly up to 2%.    But its rather like an old aged dowager, playing an old record, thinking of times that will never be; or a farm horse returning to a burned down barn.  TLDR:   The fed wants to increase rates, If they do not increase in March, that leaves May, June, Aug, Sep, Nov, December.   Three rate increases a year, with spaces to examine effects suggests  Mar/ Aug/ December. I think they are going to take a pass for March.  I think they will increase in May, and september.  Two rate increases by September 30, shading to the downside.
Business is growing and the greater fear now is overheating.

The FOMC has signaled that under its current baseline economic projections it expects to raise the fed funds rate at least three times in 2018. As the economy is doing relatively well in Q1 (as per the employment report from March 9 and the projections of the NY Fed and the Atlanta Fed ( https://www.newyorkfed.org/research/policy/nowcast and https://www.frbatlanta.org/cqer/research/gdpnow.aspx), a March hike is all but certain. Assuming the momentum will carry at least into the first half of Q2, a June hike is also a high probability. Beyond this things get a little more uncertain, but unless the economy slows down sharply in late spring/summer, a September hike seems likely as well. Now what are the main factors that would affect the economy by mid-year? The tax cuts provide some tailwind in the short run, while possible trade wars work the other way. However, provided most US allies are exempt from the recent steel and aluminum tariffs, their negative effect would be limited, I believe. And interest rates, while rising, are still low enough not to be a main drag on consumer and investment spending.    What can go wrong with this forecast? First and foremost, trade wars may materialize. Trump might refuse to exempt the European allies (NATO be damned :)), and the EU my retaliate, leading to further tit-for-tat. In such an environment, China may retaliate too, feeling emboldened by the EU reaction to the US tariffs. In such a scenario, the Fed may pause in September to assess the situation. (June should still be a hike, though). Another risk is that the market interest rates - which actually matter for the economy - may rise by more than what the Fed currently assumes. This may happen under the pressure of having to fund the sharply higher US budget deficit this year, combined with the Fed unwinding its holdings of Treasury bonds and mortgage-backed securities. Then the Fed would pause because there would be no need to raise the policy interest rate as much. But for the moment this is still a long shot - if anything, the Treasury yield curve is flatter than normal, i.e., the long-term interest rates are depressed relative to the short-term ones.
The economy is humming along nicely now, so I see another rate hike very soon.   Then another in September.

I think the odds of no increases are zero as the QE policy has met its goals for employment, inflation and the market. We also have a new fed chief. Any initial adjustment will presumably be modest which is why I think the odds favor a second increase. Conditions mitigating against about more raises are Trump’s seeming blunder with tariffs and trade wars, political instability in the White House, roiling the stock market and keeping the dollar stable.

The FOMC is meeting five times during the period covered by the question.  Current practice is to set a target within an interest rate band of a quarter percent (e.g., current policy targeting 1.25%-1.50%).  In January the Board of Governors was not aware of more recent economic information such as surprisingly strong employment growth and wage growth, record consumer credit balances, mortgage balances approaching record last set in 2008 despite higher rates, & high yield corporate debt on pace to exceed recent years even with higher rates.   This all makes it very likely that the March meeting will call for an increase in rates and the Fed will target three to four hikes for the year.  Therefore I assess the odds of less than two at 1%.  Similarly the odds of four or more for the question period is somewhat reduced because it would require either all four before the question period elapsed or a change of outlook to five or more for the year.  Because the Fed could respond to surprisingly strong growth with an increase of more than a quarter point there is the possibility of fewer rate increase decisions.  However, because the current practice of small changes then collecting more data is seen as successful, I expect the Fed will keep that practice.  I’m expecting four increases in the year with the last in December.  There is the possibility that the prospect of infrastructure spending legislation and/or protectionist policies will further stimulate domestic demand for credit making my assessment of three to four increases for the year too few.
The FOMC has meetings scheduled throughout the year, and there is internal debate about how quickly to raise rates.

"Maybe Powell Really Isn't an Inflation Hawk" https://www.bloomberg.com/view/articles/2018-03-01/powell-congressional-testimony-maybe-he-isn-t-an-
inflation-hawk "However, the economy is in an interesting position. Even as the job market has continued to strengthen, inflation has remained below the target. Furthermore, there is reason to expect that while the official unemployment rate is near record lows, there is still plenty of room for employment to grow. Over the last 17 years, the percentage of Americans in their prime working years of 25 to 54 years old who either have a job or say they are looking for a job has declined 2.3 percentage points. Once a worker gives up looking for a job, the government no longer considers him or her unemployed, but instead out of the labor force." "Fed Plans to Raise Rates in 2018 but Lacks Consensus on Frequency" https://www.nytimes.com/2018/01/03/business/economy/fed-rate-increases.html "Six of the 16 officials on the Federal Open Market Committee predicted during the December meeting that the Fed would raise rates three times in 2018. But six officials predicted two hikes or fewer and four officials predicted the Fed would raise rates at least four times." "Probability of three interest rate increases in 2018 rises over 50 per cent" https://www.ft.com/content/39b6f65d-82b5-3633-8cb9-0898aca1d5c8

The time period for this question is only just over 6 months. In the past (e.g. 2004/6)  rates have risen in a six month period 4 or 5 times from a historically low rate. The current circumstances are unusual in that the US economy seems to be running close to capacity while government policies seem to be likely to increase demand (e.g. changes to taxes) and/or prices (e.g. increases in import duties).  Import duties on steel and aluminum will likely feed straight thru to increased prices for goods made of steel and aluminum, as it would take some time for US producers to increase production to replace imports (they will probably not increase production much, and are very unlikely to invest in new plants). So an increase in prices would be good for steel and aluminum producers, but the increased prices would reduce demand for the end products (i.e. create inflation and slow the economy). If US tariff increases start a general trade war that would (obviously) be a risk to the US (and world) economy. We don't know if this will happen or not, but its clearly a risk. While this uncertainty lasts I would expect the FOMC to be cautious with rate changes. We know rate changes take about 18 months to effect an economy. The "trade war" could be all over in a week, but in the last couple of years we have seen several countries pursuing economic policies that most economists think ruinous so anything is possible. If I were setting rates, last month I might have thought 4 or 5 rate rises in the next year looked about right, the events of this month would have toned it down to 2 or 3 rises, So in six months maybe only 1 or 2, with the caveat that if the "trade war" fizzles out more rate rises can be done then.

Inflation. 4 or more is doubtful by October. Given how incompetent the WH admin is they could force the economy in to recession, which amazingly might even result in a cut!  I'm skeptical of wary of the 3 if people are basing that on wages growth and employment. But if there are 2 rises before July then I'll have to shift up to 3.
Gotta fight inflation.  Also, in order to cut rates to boost an economy, the rates have to have height!

There are 5 potential  meeting during the time period(1):
•March 20-21
•May 1-2
•June 12-13
•July 31-August 1
•September 25-26 Last year during the time period, the rate was raised twice.  It appears the group had  a habit of raising it almost every other meeting, but this was somewhat an anomaly looking at prior years going back to 2008 during the financial crisis.  It has remained relatively unchanged since.  Some analysts say they are expecting the first hike at the March meeting(2).  With 5 meetings, and the first hike likely happening at the first meeting, I doubt that "Less than 2" is likely at all, without the unknowns of an economic downturn.  Also, 4 raises does not seem possible given only 5 meetings, so it also is very unlikely,  (1)https://www.thebalance.com/fomc-meetings-schedule-and-statement-summaries-3305975
(2)https://www.housingwire.com/articles/42434-expect-first-rate-of-2018-hike-to-occur-in-march

Stupid tariff proposals notwithstanding, the tax cut means the fed with have to raise rates to contain inflation. That combined with ever lower unemployment numbers will lead the fed to raise rates several time this year. My guess is that the rate of rate increases will be similar to 2017.

The economy is accelerating.  Tariffs will not have too much impact to slow things down. They have 7 meetings remaining this year.  They like to run a steady ship.  I do not think they want to raise rates every 6 or 7 weeks, so raising rates every other meeting leads to 3 rate hikes, with one already in hand.
